verses.text: In the twenty-seventh year of Jeroboam king of Israel, Azariah son of Amaziah king of Judah began to reign.
verses.comment: Azariah is also known as Uzziah in some passages (cf. 2 Chr. 26:1).

verses.text: He was sixteen years old when he became king, and he reigned fifty-two years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Jecoliah of Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Consistent with parallel account in 2 Chronicles.

verses.text: He did what was right in the eyes of the LORD, just as his father Amaziah had done.
verses.comment: Standard formula used for assessing kings of Judah.

verses.text: Nevertheless, the high places were not removed; the people still sacrificed and burned incense on the high places.
verses.comment: High places refer to unauthorized worship sites.

verses.text: The LORD afflicted the king, so he became a leper until the day of his death. He lived in a separate house. And Jotham, the king’s son, was over the palace and governed the people of the land.
verses.comment: Leprosy rendered him unclean and removed him from public rule.

verses.text: The rest of the acts of Azariah, and all that he did, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah?
verses.comment: Standard reference to historical records.

verses.text: And Azariah slept with his fathers. They buried him with his fathers in the city of David. Then Jotham his son became king in his place.
verses.comment: ‘Slept with his fathers’ is a Hebrew idiom for death.

verses.text: In the thirty-eighth year of Azariah king of Judah, Zechariah son of Jeroboam became king over Israel in Samaria and reigned six months.
verses.comment: Beginning the account of Zechariah’s brief reign.

verses.text: He did evil in the eyes of the LORD, as his fathers had done. He did not turn away from the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat, which he made Israel to sin.
verses.comment: Common judgment on the kings of Israel.

verses.text: Shallum son of Jabesh conspired against him. He attacked him before the people, killed him, and became king in his place.
verses.comment: Emphasizes the public nature of the assassination.

verses.text: The rest of the acts of Zechariah, behold, they are written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel.
verses.comment: Formulaic concluding statement.

verses.text: This was the word of the LORD that he spoke to Jehu, saying, ‘Your sons shall sit on the throne of Israel to the fourth generation.’ And so it happened.
verses.comment: Fulfillment of prophecy given to Jehu.

verses.text: Shallum son of Jabesh became king in the thirty-ninth year of Uzziah king of Judah. He reigned one month in Samaria.
verses.comment: Uzziah and Azariah are the same ruler, as noted earlier.

verses.text: Then Menahem son of Gadi went up from Tirzah, came to Samaria, attacked Shallum son of Jabesh in Samaria, killed him, and became king in his place.
verses.comment: Describing rapid changes of regime.

verses.text: The rest of the acts of Shallum, and his conspiracy which he carried out, see, they are written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel.
verses.comment: Formulaic note.

verses.text: Then Menahem attacked Tiphsah and all who were in it and its borders, from Tirzah. Because they did not open the city to him, he attacked it. He ripped open all the pregnant women.
verses.comment: The language is graphic and reflects the brutality described in the Hebrew text.

verses.text: In the thirty-ninth year of Azariah king of Judah, Menahem son of Gadi became king over Israel and reigned ten years in Samaria.
verses.comment: Chronology continues with Menahem’s rule.

verses.text: He did evil in the eyes of the LORD. He did not turn away from the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat, which he made Israel to sin, all his days.
verses.comment: No deviation from prior idolatry.

verses.text: Then Pul king of Assyria came against the land. Menahem gave Pul a thousand talents of silver so that his hand would be with him to strengthen the kingdom in his hand.
verses.comment: Pul is Tiglath-pileser III (cf. historical sources).

verses.text: And Menahem exacted the money from Israel, from all the mighty wealthy men, fifty shekels of silver each, to give to the king of Assyria. So the king of Assyria turned back and did not stay there in the land.
verses.comment: Fifty shekels is approx. 1.25 pounds or 570 grams of silver.

verses.text: The rest of the acts of Menahem and all that he did, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel?
And Menahem slept with his fathers. Then Pekahiah his son became king in his place.
In the fiftieth year of Azariah king of Judah, Pekahiah son of Menahem became king over Israel in Samaria and reigned two years.
He did evil in the eyes of the LORD. He did not turn away from the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat, which he made Israel to sin.
Pekah son of Remaliah, his officer, conspired against him and struck him in Samaria, in the citadel of the king’s house, with Argob and Arieh. He killed him and became king in his place.
verses.comment: Argob and Arieh possibly palace officials involved or killed in the plot.

verses.text: The rest of the acts of Pekahiah and all that he did, see, they are written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel.
In the fifty-second year of Azariah king of Judah, Pekah son of Remaliah became king over Israel in Samaria and reigned twenty years.
He did evil in the eyes of the LORD. He did not turn away from the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat, which he made Israel to sin.

In the days of Pekah king of Israel, Tiglath-pileser king of Assyria came and took Ijon, Abel-beth-maacah, Janoah, Kedesh, Hazor, Gilead, Galilee, all the land of Naphtali. And he carried them captive to Assyria.
verses.comment: Documenting partial exile of Israel by Assyria.

verses.text: Then Hoshea son of Elah conspired against Pekah son of Remaliah, attacked him, killed him, and became king in his place in the twentieth year of Jotham son of Uzziah.
verses.comment: Begins transition towards the fall of Israel.

verses.text: The rest of the acts of Pekah, and all that he did, see, they are written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel.
In the second year of Pekah son of Remaliah king of Israel, Jotham son of Uzziah king of Judah began to reign.
He was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned sixteen years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Jerusha, daughter of Zadok.
verses.comment: Zadok is a prominent priestly name.

verses.text: He did what was right in the eyes of the LORD, just as his father Uzziah had done.
However, the high places were not removed; the people still sacrificed and burned incense on the high places. He built the upper gate of the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: The upper gate refers to a significant construction at the temple.

verses.text: The rest of the acts of Jotham and all that he did, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah?
verses.comment: Corresponds with parallel account in 2 Chronicles.

verses.text: In those days the LORD began to send Rezin king of Syria and Pekah son of Remaliah against Judah.
verses.comment: This military pressure sets up the events of Isaiah 7.

verses.text: Jotham slept with his fathers and was buried with his fathers in the city of David, his ancestor. Then Ahaz his son became king in his place.
verses.comment: ‘City of David’ refers to Jerusalem.
